dialogues.text: As the Executive drones on, O.S., Hudsucker is carefully  winding his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Our nominees and assigns continue  to multiply and expand extending our  influence regionally, nationally and  globally. So, third quarter and year- to-date, we've set a new record for  sales...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...new record in after-tax profit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He deliberately unstraps his wristwatch and looks at its  face. The sweep second hand is starting the last revolution tha will end at precisely noon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and our stock has split twice  this year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudsucker lays the watch carefully on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...In short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savoring a pause, the Executive looks around the board ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we're loaded.

dialogues.text: This draws an appreciative chuckle from the board. It is off by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The board turns expectantly to Hudsucker, who sits in the f.g. Beyond him is the length of the board table and the  large picture window. He rises to his feet, slowly and  deliberately, and rubs his palms together. He swings his chair out. He steps up onto the chair. The board stares. He steps up from the chair onto the board table. The heads of the board members swing up in unison. Hudsucker is FRAMED FROM MID-TORSO DOWN. He shakes the te loose from each leg, then waggles both arms dangling at h sides, like an athlete preparing for a sprint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mr. Hudsucker?

dialogues.text: Start building yours at Hudsucker Industries. Low pay. Long Hours.

dialogues.text: The hand holding the paper DROPS AWAY and we TILT UP, as  Norville walks AWAY FROM us into the b.g., towards the of building across the street. Its street number tops its  imposing entryway in large gilt letters: 285. We continue TILTING UP the length of the skyscraper, to r a huge clock capping its facade. Above the clock is the  identification "HUDSUCKER INDUSTRIES."  Below the clock i the motto "THE FUTURE IS NOW." The huge clock's sweep second hand is just approaching th position that will make the time 12:00 sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the second hand hits the twelve, the CLOCK TOLLS, the  board room WINDOW SHATTERS and Waring Hudsucker comes fly out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhh...

dialogues.text: Somewhere in the Hudsucker Building. A secretary sits typ next to an open window, finished pages sitting stacked be her. As we hear ANOTHER TOLL of the CLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: on the street, handing a steaming frank to a customer who handing him some change. As we hear the APPROACHING HUDSU both men look up. As the CLOCK TOLLS: FREEZE FRAME and SUPER A TITLE.

dialogues.text: The man, wearing a fedora, is in the f.g. of an EXTREME L ANGLE whose b.g. is the bottom three or four stories of t Hudsucker Building. FREEZE FRAME to suspend Hudsucker a good twenty feet abov the sidewalk, arms and legs splayed, comically arrested. passerby is frozen in an attitude of surprise and disbeli SUPER the title of the film: THE HUDSUCKER PROXY. UNFREEZE to send Hudsucker plummeting THROUGH the FRAME t his rendezvous with the sidewalk, BELOW FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hudsucker Building lists up into the distance. A woma in a fancy fruited hat with a black veil rises INTO FRAME an OPPOSING SLANT. Looking down at the sidewalk, she send two dismayed hands to her cheek and screeeeeeeeeams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the LAST TOLL of the CLOCK punctuating the CUT, we a FLOATING IN TOWARDS the shattered board room window. The woman's SCREAM on the street below is FAINT, ECHOING, MIXING INTO the sound of an APPROACHING SIREN. THROUGH the window we see the BOARD MEMBERS still sitting around the table, paralyzed in attitudes of horror and  disbelief. All stare at the shattered window in the f.g. At the far end of the table, Hudsucker's chair is empty a oddly askew. His cigar still smokes in its ashtray. There are dust footprints down the middle of the long oak table. One Executive sits with a pluming cigarette held halfway his mouth; another holds a carafe suspended on its way to his water glass; another holds his spectacles inches from his nose. We hear only the HUM of the HUDSUCKER CLOCK. SID MUSSBURGER ENTERS FRAME at the window. He is a tall m aged executive with lean and rugged good looks and a  commanding presence. He knocks a last piece of glass out of the sill with his  knuckle, looks out, grunts, and draws his head back in. The CAMERA FOLLOWS him INTO the room. The other board mem heads swivel to watch him, all staring, searching despera for some hint as to the fate of their fallen leader.  Apparently, some absurd hope still lingers. Mussburger perches on the board table by his own chair. He reaches over to pluck the smoking cigar from the suici ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity to waste a whole Monte Cristo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other board members unfreeze, their worst fears confi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could've opened the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waring Hudsucker never did anything  the easy way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, why?! Why did he do it?! Things were going so well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I a headshrinker? Maybe the  man was unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't look unhappy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, he didn't look rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waring Hudsucker was never an easy  man to figure out. (reminiscing) He built this company with his bare  hands. Every step he took was a step  up. Except of course this last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, he was a swell guy, but  when the president, chairman of the  board and holder of eighty-seven  percent of the company's stock drops  forty-four floors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counting the mezzanine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Then the company has a problem. Stillson, what exactly is the  disposition of Waring's stock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as you know, Hud left no will  and had no family. The company bylaws  are quite clear in that event. His  entire portfolio will be converted  to common stock and will be sold  over the counter as of the first of  the fiscal year following his demise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning simply that Waring's stock,  and control of the company, will be  available to the public on January  first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me that any slob in  a smelly T-shirt will be able to buy  Hudsucker stock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stillson shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company bylaws are quite clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God! You're animals! How can you  discuss his stock when the man has  just leapt forty-five floors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-four --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Not counting the mezzanine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit showboating, Addison, the man  is gone. The question now is whether  we're going to let John Q. Public  waltz in and buy 87 percent of our  company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you suggesting, Sidney? Certainly we can't afford to buy a  controlling interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not while the stock is this strong. How long before Hud's paper hits the  market?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: January first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month at the most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One month to make the blue-chip  investment of the century look like  a round-trip ticket on the Titanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We play up the fact that Hud is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison) Long live the Hud!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We depress the stock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to the point where we can buy  fifty-percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not counting the mezzanine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at ticker tape machine) It's working already. Waring Hudsucker  is abstract art on Madison Avenue.  All we need now is a new president  who will inspire real panic in our  stockholders.

dialogues.text: Sure, sure. Some jerk we can really  push around.

dialogues.text: The ANCIENT SORTER considers this as he continues whiskin his mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Mail carts and other paraphernalia are abruptly swept out the crowded aisle to form a clear path running down to an elevator in the b.g. With a SIREN SOUND, a light above the elevator goes on. The elevator door sweeps open. It reveals a wall into whi a four-foot high hinged door is set. This door swings open and an old dwarf emerges: Old man  HUTCHINSON, the boss of the mailroom. He emerges from the blinding light of the interior of the elevator. He is holding aloft a letter. He takes loping drawf strides down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: LETTER
dialogues.text: TRACKING ON letter as Hutchinson bears it along. In the b the faces that the letter passes are agog. CROSSCUT the approaching blue letter WITH: Norville and t Ancient Sorter.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Ancient Sorter is leaning over to whisper into Norvil ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a blue letter... top, top  level... confidential communication  between the brass... usually bad  news... they hate blue letters  upstairs... Hate 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville looks over his shoulder, but the Ancient Sorter disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, you! Barnes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he points, the people around Norville shrink away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You don't look busy! Think you  can handle a blue letter? (laughs sadistically) ...This letter was sent down this  morning by the big guy himself! 'At's  right, Waring Hudsucker! It's  addressed to Sid Mussburger!   Hudsucker's right-hand man! It's a  blue letter! That means you put it  right in Mussburger's hand. No  secretaries! No receptionists! No  colleagues! No excuses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRAMATIC TRACK IN ON Norville. As Hutchinson talks, he th the blue letter into Norville's face. Norville looks at i with terrific apprehension. As Hutchinson's speech ends, are TIGHT ON Norville's sweating face.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHINSON
dialogues.text: We can see the veins in his eyes, the veins in his nose, hairs in his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger!!

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR DOORS
dialogues.text: ROCKETING OPEN. We MOVE IN ON the young elevator operator who leers INTO CAMERA. He wears a brass-buttoned uniform, white gloves and a pillbox hat. The name BUZZ is stitched onto his breast pocket. As Norville enters the elevators:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, buddy! The name is Buzz, I got  the fuzz...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts his pillbox hat to reveal a white crewcut, then  lets the elastic chin strap snap the cap back down onto h head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I make the elevator do what she  duzz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand but as Norville reaches to shake it snaps it away and pats down his crewcut:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hang it up to dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cackles and powers the ELEVATOR into GEAR. Norville's  knees buckle under a huge upward surge; Buzz is accustome to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's your pleasure, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regaining his balance) Forty-fourth floor, and it's very --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-four, the top brass floor say,  buddy! What takes fifty years to get  up to the top floor and thirty seconds  to get down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waring Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha-ha!  Say, buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a powerful DOWN-SHIFTING SOUND, Buzz brakes the elev to a sharp halt. Norville continues upward with the inert painfully smacking his head against a corner of the eleva Buzz opens the door and a couple of people enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kline, up to nine. Mrs. Dell,  personnel. Mr. Levin, thirty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk down. Ladies and gentlemen,  step to the rear; here comes  gargantuan Mr. Grier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An obese MAN enters, smoking a cigar:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz has already thrown the doors shut and sent the eleva into its power-rise. Norville, bracing himself now, sinks only a little under the G-force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, buddy! Who's the most liquid  businessman on the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waring Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha-ha! Say, buddy! When is the sidewalk  fully dressed? When it's 'wearing'  Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to look at Norville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ya get it, buddy, it's a pun,  it's a knee-slapper, it's a play on  Jesus, Joseph and Mary, is that a  blue letter?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All heads in the elevator turn, aghast, to look, and thos near Norville shrink away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Cripes a'mighty, whyn't ya tell a  guy?! Hold on, folks, we're express  to the top floor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ELEVATOR SCREAMS into overdrive and we:

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR DOORS
dialogues.text: Sweeping open. Norville staggers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hissing) Good luck, buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door sweeps shut. Norville looks nervously around. Behind him the elevator doors suddenly open again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You'll need it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors slam shut and we hear its ENGINES SCRE as it power-dives away. Norville turns toward the executive offices. Plush, thick-carpeted silence. Norville starts walking. A SCRAPING SOUND stands out in the high-powered executive quiet. Norville looks to one side. A workman in painter's overalls squats in front of a pair heavy oak doors. With a razor blade he is scraping off th name "WARING HUDSUCKER."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mr. Mussburger's office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scraper looks sullenly over his shoulder at Norville. With a jerk of his thumb he indicates the direction. Norville enters the adjacent office.

dialogues.speaker: OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Two secretaries are in Mussburger's outer reception offic The first is a filing secretary who stands frozen in the  f.g., her hand poised over an open drawer to deposit a fo as she stares at Norville with an amused and supercilious sneer which stays pasted on throughout. The second secretary -- the RECEPTIONIST -- is seated beh a desk in the b.g. that flanks the door to Mussburger's  private office. The Receptionist sits with her hands clas on the desk, staring at Norville with the hunch-shouldere down-from-under look of a patient vulture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh, no, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The filing secretary sneers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we look in the book, hmmmmmmmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens an enormous leather-bound book with yellowed cr pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, ya see, I wouldn't be in  the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't seem to be in the boooook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is groping in his apron pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, ya see I don't have an --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we had an appointment we'd be in  the booook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but ya see I have this --  here it is, this letter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low, unearthly WAIL fills the room, the sound of a mill souls moaning in purgatory. The Receptionist looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FAST TRACK IN ON SNEERING FILE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: who is no longer sneering. Her mouth is stretched wide as she wails and her finger points...

dialogues.speaker: FAST TRACK IN ON BLUE LETTER
dialogues.text: that Norville holds innocently at his side.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TRACK IN ON WAILING SECRETARY
dialogues.text: As her wail becomes deafening and we TRACK INTO her mouth and the SCREEN GOES BLACK and:

dialogues.speaker: CLICK
dialogues.text: The blackness and the wailing are both cut short by the s of a DOOR OPENING. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: its door swinging open to admit Norville. In the b.g., in the outer office, we can see the filing  secretary leaning back motionless in a chair with a damp draped across her forehead. The Receptionist is fanning h with a towel. The door closes behind Norville. We hear a rhythmic CLICK-CLICK-CLICK and the HUM of  VENTILATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across miles of carpet is a huge executive desk, behind w is a large executive chair facing the window. From above back of the chair cigar smoke wreathes up. A telephone co snakes around to the man sitting in the chair, hidden fro us. On the desktop is a perpetual motion machine of large swinging ball bearings. Click-click-click. A TICKERTAPE MACHINE occasionally BURPS information in th far corner of the office. A huge MECHANICAL ARM -- the sweep second hand of the  Hudsucker clock on the facade of the building -- RUMBLES immediately outside the window, describing an arc that th a moving shadow across the office. His BACK TO us, into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Sure sure, Parkinson's stupid but  he's ambitious, too hard to control...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swivels around to face Norville, who stands deferentia at the door. Still listening at the phone, Mussburger wav Norville forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No! Not McClanahan; sure he bungled  the Teleyard merger, but that means  he's got something to prove...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He covers the mouth piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who let you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atwater? Tremendous. Except I fired  him last week --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INTERCOM BUZZES fiercely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bumstead is waiting downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger hits the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'll be right there... (looks at Norville) Well, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mussburger is listening to the TINNY VOICE issuing fr the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, maybe you're the company's  biggest moron. We can't use Morris,  he's been with us too long, he's a  nice guy, too many friends. Matter  of fact, why don't you fire him. No --  scratch that; I'll fire him. (looks up at Norville) ...Make it fast, make it fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INTERCOM SQUAWKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bumstead is getting very --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right there. Give him a  magazine. (to Norville) ...What're you, a mute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second PHONE on Mussburger's desk RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, how's the stock doing? ...Bad, huh? Well it's not bad enough. (into the first phone) ...Look, chump, either you find me a  grade A ding-dong or you can tender  your key to the executive washroom. (into the second phone) And that goes double for you. (into the first phone) Ear-clay? (into both phones) Ood-gay! (slams down both  phones, looks at  Norville) This better be good. I'm in a bad  mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir. I've got something for  you from the mailroom, but first if  I could just take a minute or so  from your very busy time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his mailroom apron and hands a scrap of p across the desk to Mussburger, who stares, frozen, at  Norville, making no move to take the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to show you a, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, undaunted, holds up the paper since Mussburger  will not take it. Mussburger doesn't even look at it; his eyes are locked on Norville's. Mussburger smolders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a little something I've been  working on for the last two or three  years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger's burning eyes finally shift momentarily to lo at the crudely drawn circle; he looks back incredulously Norville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know, for kids! Which is  perfect for Hudsucker -- not that I  claim to be any great genius; like  they say, inspiration is 99 percent  perspiration, and in my case I'd say  it's at least twice that, but I gotta  tell ya, Mr. Mussburger, sir, this  sweet baby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sudden quiet. With one last click the perpetual motion ball bearings  abruptly stop. As Mussburger's eyes burn in on him, Norville stands mute and paralyzed. His eyes locked on Norville's, Mussburger circles the des He stands toe-to-toe with Norville. He thrusts his face into Norville's, whose head moves  reflexively back. Mussburger's nose is almost touching  Norville's, his eyes are burning, searching, studying,  evaluating. Finally he draws his head back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With one hand he thrusts his cigar into Norville's gaping mouth. With his other hand he raises Norville's chin so t his teeth clench it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm-hmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps back, eyes still on Norville. He jerks his thumb over his shoulder, indicating his chai behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siddown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, his lips puckered around the unaccustomed ciger looks bemusedly from the chair to Mussburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Go ahead. Try it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville obeys, reluctantly, stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Put your feet up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is again reluctant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville obeys. Mussburger studies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm... Let's get to know one  another, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville's eyes squint against the cigar smoke wreathing  from between his teeth. Mussburger seems to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Let's chat! (beams) ...Man to man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You weren't blessed with much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves vaguely towards his head and searches for a  euphemism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...education, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm a college graduate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but you didn't excel in  your studies...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I made the dean's list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville sputters out some more cigar smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Muncie College of Business  Administration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Sure, sure. And did your classmates  there call you 'jerk' or... (searches again) ...'schmoe'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...'Shnook'? 'Dope'? 'Dipstick'?  'Lamebrain'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even behind your back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir! They voted me most likely to  succeed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly) You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, sir! --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your feet off that desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he struggles to comply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, squinting against the cigar smoke, pulls the ci out of his mouth as he doubles forward, feet still up, gr for a place to set down the cigar. He sets it blindly on loose stack of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God! The Bumstead contracts!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top page radiates a circle of incipient flame from th cigar's live end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nitwit! I worked for three years  on this deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville runs across the office to a large water cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it. Just get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger plucks the cigar off the contract and tosses i into a wastebasket. He pats the fingertips of one hand ag his tongue and then efficiently pats out the crinkling or circle on the top sheet of the contract. At the other end of the office, Norville is wrapping his  arms around the glass water tank, which he pulls off its  base. He runs back across the vast expanse of office towa the desk, hugging the water tank whose WATER GLOOB-GLOOBS out its open bottom and splashes down onto his pumping kn As he reaches the desk, the near-empty tank is now light  enough for him to hoist with one arm, which he does, and  cups his other hand under it to catch its last glub of wa He tosses the TANK to the floor where -- CRASH -- it SHATTERS, and stands looking about for a plac to dump his handful of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you nitwit. You almost destroyed  the most sensitive deal of my career!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is reacting to the wastebasket on his side of the desk which Mussburger cannot see. It is sprouting flame, at which Norville ineffectually fl his remaining drops of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now out of here! Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is already running to the window, which he runs  both palms over, desperately seeking a way to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that way! Through the door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows do not open. Norville furiously stomps on the flames in the wastebasket and -- his foot sticks. Further stomping only makes the flaming wastebasket roar and down with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away, buster! Out of my office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville has dropped to the floor, trying to wrench the  flaming wastebasket off his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up on your feet! We don't crawl at  Hudsucker Industries!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, my leg is on fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville finally succeeds in getting the flaming wastebas off his foot. Now the problem is what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of this office, you dithering  nincompoop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville picks up the flaming trash receptacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winds up and throws it through the closed window. The GLASS SHATTERS and the flaming basket plummets to  oblivion. With the picture window broken a FEROCIOUS DRAFT ROARS th the penthouse office.

dialogues.speaker: BUMSTEAD CONTRACTS
dialogues.text: On the desk. The pages are sucked away by the draft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God! The Bumstead contracts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger lunges for the contracts as they are sucked ou the window. He runs, jumps onto the sill, grabs -- his fist clenches  around one wafting page -- he is about to fall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eeeeeeaaaahhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUMSTEAD, a short, fat, heavily perspiring executive, is  screaming at an O.S. secretary. He holds a pot of coffee one hand and a copy of Boy's Life in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No magazine. No coffee. Mussburger!  I wanna see Mussburger! Or did he  jump out a window too?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the window behind him we see loose sheets of paper  fluttering down.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Desperately hanging onto Mussburger by his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mr. Mussburger! I gotcha.  I gotcha by your pants!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger's screaming abruptly stops.

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER
dialogues.text: is in a basement tailor shop. LUIGI, an old Italian tailo is just running his tape up Mussburger's inseam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meester Moosaburger, I give-a you  pants a nice-a dooble stitch. Make  'em strong, and they look-a real  sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking) No! Single stitch is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begging) But please-a, Meester Moosaburger,  the dooble stitch she last-a forever --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why on earth would I need a double  stitch? To pad your bill? Single  stitch is fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a LOUD TEARING sound O.S. Mussburger drops a few  inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing to himself) What the heck. Meester Moosaburger  such a nice-a guy, I give him dooble  steech-a anyway. Assa some-a strong- a steech-a, you bet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tearing fabric abruptly catches and stops; the rest o the pants hold intact.

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER
dialogues.text: sighs with relief. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Norville's arms are wrapped around Mussburger's ankles; t heels of Mussburger's shoes are digging into his face.

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER
dialogues.text: Looking. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Struggling to hold on.

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER
dialogues.text: Calm. Contemplating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He absently removes a cigar from his breast pocket and st it in his mouth. He holds his lighter under the cigar, no noticing that the flame is pointing the wrong way. He looks at Norville.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: His face drawn with effort, still struggling to hang on. A PULL BACK FROM the EXTREME CLOSE SHOT REVEALS, however, that Norville's arms are now wrapped around -- emptiness. Mussburger's legs are gone. Norville throws his head back and laughs, it seems, insan but CONTINUED PULL BACK REVEALS that Norville is merely  pantomiming the adventure for the benefit of the board  members, including Mussburger. They stand around Mussburg office, laughing gaily. All safe now, no harm done. This  inaugurates:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montage silent but for MUSIC. A) Norville is entertaining the board with his depiction the near-disaster. Mussburger is slapping him merrily on back. B) CLOSE SHOT - Board member laughing. C) Another board member. Laughing. D) Mussburger. Laughing. E) Norville laughing. F) FREEZE FRAME ON Norville's laughing face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal that the frozen picture is the newspa photo on the front page of the Manhattan Argus. Its headline reads: UNTRIED YOUTH TO HELM HUDSUCKER. The subhead reads: Stockholders Wary. The sub-subhead rea Meteoric Rise From Mailroom. The article is under the byline of Amy Archer. CONTINUED PULL BACK REVEALS that we are looking at the  newspaper OVER someone's SHOULDER. The person swivels aro and away -- his face now TO us, we see that it is Norvill looking at the newspaper. He throws his head back and lau merrily. As he laughs -- thwock -- a steaming towel is thrown onto his face and he continues to swivel. CONTINUED PULL BACK  REVEALS that he is in a barber chair. His head drops back and OUT OF FRAME as the swiveling cha is cranked down, but immediately -- still spinning -- -- his head reappears as the chair is cranked up again. Still laughing, Norville is now freshly shaven and has a  slicked-back haircut, heavy with pomade. FREEZE ON Norville's laughing face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal it is another front page photo next t the headline: Hud Board To Street: GIVE MAN FROM MUNCIE A CHANCE. Subhead: Has Fresh Ideas. CONTINUED PULL BACK REVEALS that the paper is lying on a  chair. Norville's mailroom apron is tossed onto the chair cover it. PAN TO where the apron was tossed from. Norville stands o tailor's stage, laughing, as the tailor, also laughing, t his measurements. Norville in shirtsleeves, boxer shorts, hose stockings and garters. The tailor rises, laughing merrily, throwing up his arms spreading them wide with hands stretching the measuring t Norville laughs merrily and also throws his arms up wide.

dialogues.speaker: BOARD MEMBER
dialogues.text: laughs merrily, his arms thrown wide, tickertape stretchi between his hands. He joyously tosses away the tickertape

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR
dialogues.text: where the tickertape lands on a pile of previously discha tape. PAN UP to reveal that the tickertape continues to burp it disastrous tale of good news for the board. PAN UP FURTHER to reveal that the machine is in Mussburge office. At the far end of the room, behind his desk,  Mussburger laughs as he looks at a newspaper. TRACK IN TOWARDS him. On his desk the perpetual ballbearings swing; outside his window the sweep second hand of the Hudsucker clock rumbl by, sweeping a shadow across the floor. Evil prevails. As Mussburger opens the newspaper, the CONTINUED TRACK IN shows its front page headline: HUD STOCK DIPS. Subhead: J Good Is He? TRACK IN ON the front page photo: Norville laughing, his  chin propped in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: COMES TO LIFE and Norville unfreezes, laughing. We are now TRACKING BACK FROM him. He sits behind a huge desk, newly coifed and tailored. The brass plaque on the desk confirms that he is in the O OF THE PRESIDENT. TRACK BACK CONTINUES THROUGH the large elegant office, le Norville looking quite small IN LONG SHOT. His LAUGHTER ECHOES in the bright bare office. Norville's laughter is just winding down, leaving him  exhausted, as if he has been laughing nonstop for several days. He finally sighs and wipes a tear from his eye.

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK SKYLINE
dialogues.text: In the skyline we can see the Hudsucker building topped b the Hudsucker clock. A cigar ENTERS FRAME in the f.g., then the face of the ma smoking it. Staring contemplatively at the Hudsucker buil he takes a puff from the cigar and then plucks it from hi mouth and waves it, as if painting a headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Einstein of Enterprise.' 'The  Edison of Industry.' 'The Billion- Dollar Cranium'... 'Idea Man'! (exploding) And not one of you mugs has given me  a story on him!!

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: shows the Editors glassed-in office filled with REPORTERS for the staff meeting. Although they listen quietly, they are more bored than attentive. THROUGH the glass walls we can see the furious activity o an army of reporters, editors, and copy boys waging the n ending battle to put out a quality daily newspaper. The Editor slams a newspaper down onto his desk in disgus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facts, figures, charts! They never  sold a newspaper! I read this  morning's edition of the Argus and  let me tell you something: I'd wrap  a fish in it!  I'd use it as kindling!  Hell, I'd even train my poodle with  it if he wasn't a French poodle and  more partial to the pages of Paree  Soir! But I sure wouldn't shell out  a hard-earned nickel to read the  dadblamed thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, chief, give us a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suuuure, Tibbs, take a break! Go to  Florida! Lie in the sun! Wait for a  coconut to drop, file a story on it --  it'll be more of a grabber than your  piece on the commie grain surplus!  The human angle! That's what sells  papers! We need a front page with  heart and the whole idea of the 'Idea  Man' idea can put it there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, if we had more access --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and if a frog had wings he  wouldn't bump his ass a-hoppin'! I  don't want excuses, I want results!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whack! -- Without even looking in its direction, the Editor has sla down the lid of the cigar box on his desk, towards which Reporter's hand had been idly reaching. The Reporter jerks his fingers away as the Editor spares briefest moment to glare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna know what makes the Idea Man  tick! Where is he from? Where is he  going? I wanna know everything about  this guy! Has he got a girl? Has he  got parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, how many? How 'bout it,  Parkinson, you've been awful quiet  over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still waters run deep, chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing that runs deep with  Parkinson is the holes in his ears. Yes, the Idea Man! What're his hopes  and dreams, his desires and  aspirations? Does he think all the  time or does he set aside a certain  portion of the day? How tall is he  and what's his shoe size? Where does  he sleep and what does he eat for  breakfast? Does he put jam on his  toast or doesn't he put jam on his  toast, and if not why not and since  when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thrust his face into that of the Reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ahh, you're useless. Yes, Idea  Man! Creator! Innovator! Cerebrator!  Tycoon!--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huhh!!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Star reporter AMY ARCHER -- attractive, smartly-dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell ya the guy's a phony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phony, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a three-dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sez who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sez me! Amy Archer. Why is he an  Idea Man -- because Hudsucker says  he is? What're his ideas? Why won't  they let anyone interview him?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Reporter is leaning into another to keep his voice lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five bucks says she mentions her  Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again? You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she picks up the  morning paper) ...And just take a look at the mug  on this guy -- the jutting eyebrows,  the simian forehead, the idiotic  grin. Why he has a face only a mother  could love --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whack! The Editor has slammed down the cigar box lid agai but: Amy, smiling, raises a cigar INTO FRAME having beate him. She tosses it to the Reporter who failed to get one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...On payday! The only story here is  how this guy made a monkey out of  you, Al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, monkey or not I'm still  editor of this rag. Amy, I thought  you were doing that piece on the  F.B.I. -- J. Edgar Hoover: When Will  He Marry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I filed it yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do a follow-up: Hoover: Hero  or Mama's Boy? The rest of you bums  get up off your brains and get me  that Idea Man story!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, chief... We'll do our  best, chief... I'll give it a shot,  chief...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) Al, he's the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slam! One of the wagering Reporters grins at the other, who is  taking out a five dollar bill. The door bursts open and Amy sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stake my Pulitzer on it!

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR DOORS
dialogues.text: Sweeping open to reveal the leering face of Buzz, the ele gnat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, buddy! Where'd ya get the new  duds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is entering the elevator in his new executive ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and say, buddy! How'd old  bucketbutt like his blue letter? Na-ha-ha-ha-ha! Did he bust a gut?  Did he die? Did he -- Well, hello,  Mr. Mussburger, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz is instant decorum as Mussburger enters the elevator

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How're you this fine morning,  sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville has been worriedly patting at his pockets since mention of the blue letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That reminds me, Mr. Mu... uh, Sid.  I never did give you that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Buzz) Lobby. We haven't got all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away, Mr. Mussburger sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he talks, Mussburger pats at his suit pocket, takes ou cigar, inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm starved. I understand it'll  be quite an affair this afternoon,  and the executive roast tom turkey  at the Bohemian Grove redefines the  word superb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the cigar in his mouth and Buzz's hand is right t with a lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roast tom turkey. Gee, I'm hungry  too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a pleasure serving you,  Mr. Mussburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz turns to Norville. He is puzzled but trying to hide

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and it's been a pleasure serving  you too, uh... buddy.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MUSSBURGER
dialogues.text: is already striding through the lobby; Norville has to lo to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid! Shouldn't  we be a little bit concerned with  the downward spiral of our stock  these last few days? I mean, you're  the expert, but at the Muncie College  of Business Administration they told  us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger gives an artificially hearty laugh and claps  Norville on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Norville. It's only natural  in a period of transition for the  more nervous element to run for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Sid. Like I said, you're the  expert, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is still loping behind Mussburger, trying to kee up with his long strides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You don't happen to remember the  plan I outlined to you the day I set  fire to your off -- uh, the day I  was promoted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do remember and I was impressed. Anyway, that's all forgotten now.  Driver!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sid, but the reason I  mention it is, it would require such  a small capital investment -- again,  you're the expert here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit, where's my car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- But there's such an enormous  potential profit-wise given the  demographics -- baby boom -- discretionary income in the burgeoning  middle class --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black limousine pulls up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- So if you think it's appropriate,  I'd like to bounce the idea off a  few people at lunch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger is getting into the back seat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, tell whoever you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, to Norville's surprise, slamming the door shut behin him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And I'd like to hear more about  it at some point, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREEEECH -- the CAR pulls away. Norville is left talking himself on the empty sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Sid, I thought you and I were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, bud, could you keep the sidewalk  clear here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm the president of this --  aww, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheap coffee shop a half-flight down from the street. We are LOOKING ACROSS an elbow of the coffee shop counter In the middle b.g., Norville sits dejectedly stirring a c of coffee. Behind him, THROUGH the window wells, we see the back and forth feet of pedestrians bustling by on the sidewalk. In the extreme f.g. sit two steaming mugs of coffee. They belong to two VETERANS of the coffee shop, who, from O.S., narrate the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got gas, Bennie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kiddin', Bennie. I got gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya get the special?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fah from it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a low whistle under his breath as a woman enters from the street and hesitates by the door, looking around Still attractive but looking somewhat down-at-the-heels, is Amy Archer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Enter the dame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one in every story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten bucks says she's looking for a  handout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty bucks says not here she don't  find one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's looking for her mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman's eyes settle on Norville, and she heads for th empty stool next to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman says something to the counter waitress, who exi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and awduhs a light lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks in her purse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is holding her wallet upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mark notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Norville, however, is not noticing: He is staring  intently at his coffee spoon, his hat pushed back on his  head, his other hand propping up a cheekbone; the woman's presence does not seem to have registered yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's not noticing, Benny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't look wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plan two: Here come the waterworks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellowstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Faithful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Niagara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the woman cries, she accidentally-on-purpose jostles  Norville and he finally does indeed notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman mouths words at Norville who reacts sympathetic and waves his hands at the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She explains her perdicament, and... VETERAN #1 & #2 (O.S.) (in unison) ...entuh the light lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress is entering to set a plate in front of the w The woman continues to talk to Norville, smiling wanly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got other problems, of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Her mother needs an operation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...adenoids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bennie: Lumbago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veteran #1's enunciation of "lumbago" falls into perfect  sync with the woman's moving lips. Norville is listening sympathetically, but he suddenly no his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) She's losing him, Bennie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is rising to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't look wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norville turns to leave:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does she pull this out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the back of her hand dramatically to her forehea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) She isn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled) She is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And indeed she does: Faint dead away, falling backwards o the stool, so that Norville has no choice but to catch he Norville holds her awkwardly, looking around for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good, Bennie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's damn good, Lou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS enters extreme f.g. to BLOCK OUR VIEW of the  swooned woman and the embarrassed Norville. The Waitress FACING the CAMERA and the two O.S. Veterans; the CROPPING gives us only her torso and the steaming pot of coffee sh holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bored, nasal voice) Can I get you boys anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back of the Waitress's torso in f.g.; on either side beyo her, the two Veterans are looking up at her O.S. face. Th sport extremely bored expressions, topped by "cabbie" cap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bromo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Bromo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at its frosted-glass door; the sign painter is ju finishing lettering in: NORVILLE BARNES, President. The sign painter makes way as we see Norville's shadow  approaching; even from inside the room we can hear that h is WHEEZING HEAVILY. He is apparently carrying the girl,  cradled in his arms. He tries to reach down to get the  doorknob; can't manage it; turns to press his back agains the door and get the knob with his other hand. The door opens as Norville swings around to enter. He is  wheezing like a gas pipe about to explode. He swings around to kick the door shut. We see that the  lettering on the door is now terribly smudged; we also se in wet ink, on the seat of Norville's pants: senraB elliv tnediserP. Weakly, still cradled in Norville's arms:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we had to take the stairs.  It was just that horrible little  elevator boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. You're light as a feather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing languorously) The couch, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still wheezing horribly, Norville staggers over to the co and deposits her gently on it. He straightens up and look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is smiling wanly AT the CAMERA. The entire IMAGE PULS as the blood pounds behind Norville's eyeballs. We hear the LOUD, RASPING of his BREATH, resonating insid his head. Amy is talking but her voice is barely audible, if coming from a long way away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He perches drunkenly on the edge of the couch and puts hi head between his knees, still fighting for breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what came over me. I  suppose it was the shock of eating  after so long without; the enzymes  kicking in after so long, or whatever.  But then you couldn't possibly know  what it is to be tired and hungry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking into his knees as he wheezes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to bore you with all  the sordid details of my life; it's  not a happy story...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville rises and starts putting throw pillows behind he head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Suffice it to say that I'm jobless --  though not for want of trying, that  I'm friendless, with no one to --  thank you -- take care of me; and  that had you not come along at just  exactly the moment that you did --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She screams, staring down at the couch. Norville jumps, startled, then looks where she is looking On the white sofa cushion where he had been sitting is  printed, in wet ink, right side around: NORVILLE BARNES,  President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, I didn't know you were  president here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville stares dumbfounded at the sofa cushion. When the nickel finally drops, he spins around to try to look at t seat of his pants. Distracted but still modest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing really. Just  determination and hard work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unbuckles his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Of course, when I started in the  mailroom last Tuesday I thought it  might take more time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz enters holding a brown paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, buddy, here's the whiskey you  asked f --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He freezes, taking in the scene: Amy reclining on the cou Norville standing in front of her with his pants around h ankles, still breathing heavily; the bottle of whiskey in his own hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) Thank you, Buzz, just leave it on  the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy days, buddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns to leave:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I'll tell your secretary you're  not to be disturbed. Yowzuh!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps the elastic strap under his chin. After the doors shut behind Buzz:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuddering) What a horrible little person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Buzz is pretty harmless, really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At any rate I arrived in town not  ten days ago, full of dreams and  aspirations, anxious to make my way  in the world --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville pours a glass of whiskey and brings it over to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little naive perhaps but -- thank  you -- armed with determination, a  solid work ethic, and an indomitable  belief in the future --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I myself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses back to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only to have that belief, that  unsullied optimism, dashed against  the marble and mortar of the modern  work place --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville takes a cigarette from a large wood cigarette bo on the desk and sticks it in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. Seek and ye shall find,  work and ye shall prosper -- these  were the watch words of my education,  the ethics of my tender years --

dialogues.speaker: OVER NORVILLE'S SHOULDER
dialogues.text: He has been pushing the box towards her. The box tilts la forward and then disappears over the far lip of the desk. hear the THUD of the BOX landing amid the pitter-patter o cigarettes raining onto the carpet. Amy's brow crinkles. Continuing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- these were the values that were  instilled in me while I was growing  up in a little town you've probably  never heard of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I join you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is pouring himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be my guest. A little town you've  probably --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses back his drink, gags, looks at Amy with his eye bulging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again her IMAGE PULSATES. There is a ROARING SOUND a an AIRY STEAM WHISTLE as she silently moves her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves his arms and talks with a  thick rasp as he staggers to his  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- I -- executive  washroom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers out a side door. On his exit Amy leaps to her feet and scurries over to hi desk. At the top of her voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws open the top desk drawer. Inside two lonely le pencils roll through the otherwise empty drawer. Amy expertly flips a cigarette into her mouth and strikes match off the desktop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Is it your lunch? The chicken a  la king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the washroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy throws open another drawer, empty except for an  appointment book. As she hurriedly flips through page aft blank page an arctic WIND WHISTLES emptiness. One page on has a notation: 11:45. Address Wilkie Grammar School Juni Achievers Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the a la king repeating on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy shoves the appointment book back into the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm fine, I... You were saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She mutters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Values... watchwords... uh, tender  years... (aloud) -- A little town you've probably  never heard of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hastily stubs out her cigarette and waves her hand to disperse the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Muncie, Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scurries back across the room as we hear the FAUCET B TURNED OFF: she re-strikes her languid pose on the couch  just as the washroom door opens. Norville gapes, one hand pressing a dripping rag to his  forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from Muncie?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why yes, do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville starts making pumping motions with his fists and loud syncopated grunting noises. Amy gapes at him. He starts singing, off-key:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fight on fight on dear old Muncie  Fight on -- Hoist the gold and blue  You'll be tattered, torn and hurtin' Once 'The Munce' is done with you!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy lamely fakes singing along, coming in louder on the l obvious rhyme. Norville jumps an octave on it; she quickl follows sit, also pumping her fists. As Norville crosses his hands and locks thumbs in front o his nose to make bird wings of his extended fingers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Goooooooo Eagles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy awkwardly imitates. Norville excitedly sits behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A Muncie girl! Talk about the  cat's pyjamas! Tell you what, Amy. I'm gonna cancel the rest of my  appointments this afternoon and get  you a job here at the Hud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, really, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother to thank me, it's the  easiest thing in the world. Matter  of fact, I know where a vacancy just  came up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mail room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Amy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This'll only take a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon to ya, this is Norville  Barnes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnes! Where the hell have you been!  And where's my voucher?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville thumps at his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, I'm not sure where I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need that voucher! I told you a  week ago it was important!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But look, I'm president of the company  now and I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if you're president of  the company! I need that voucher!  Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK. The intercom goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of all the foolish... Listen, do  you take shorthand? Are you familiar  with the mimeograph machine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course -- I went to the Muncie,  uh, Secretarial Polytechnic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville excitedly smacks a fist into a palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A Muncie girl! Can you beat that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I just don't know how to thank  you, Mr. Barnes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Norville!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reaches to shake:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's my pleasure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for his hand but Norville snatches it away an winking at her, hooks thumbs in front of his nose and mak wings of his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gooooooo Eagles!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: likewise hooks her thumbs in front of her nose, makes win and, winking back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gooooooooo Eagles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we PULL BACK to reveal that the girl is now in a news office, demonstrating the fight sign to SMITTY, a reporte wearing a fedora with a bent-back brim. Smitty howls with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheezing) ...Once 'The Munce'... Holy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy sits down behind a typewriter and, as she starts typi at 80 words per minute:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And is this guy from chumpsville?! I pulled the old mother routine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adenoids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lumbago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind her an ancient man wearing an inksman's visor and  sleeve garters toils over a large checkerboarded surface  over which he shuffles letter blocks and black spaces. Smitty gives a low whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gag's got whiskers on it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS and Smitty reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Smitty, the board  of Hudsucker is up to something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Amy, what's a six-letter word  for an affliction of the hypothalmus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a break in her typing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And it's a cinch -- Goiter --  it's a cinch this guy isn't in on  it. How much time to make the Late  Final?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smitty holds the phone away from his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still typing, Amy whistles and nods to her shoulder. Smitty tucks the phone into it as she continues typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Chief, just the person I wanted  to apologize to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smitty is looking at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About seven minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still typing) Yeah, I was all wet about your idea  man... Well, thanks for being so  generous... It is human, and you are  divine... No, he's no faker. He's  the 100% real McCoy beware-of- imitations genuine article: the guy  is a real moron --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Ancient Puzzler:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as in a five-letter word for  imbecile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back into phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as pure a specimen as I've ever  run across... Am I sure he's a nitwit?  Heck, if working at the Argus doesn't  make me an expert then my name isn't  Amy Archer and I've never won the  Pulitzer Prize...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...In 1957... My series on the  reunited triplets -- come on down  here, hammerhead, and I'll show it  to ya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy, what's a three-letter word for  a flightless bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Morris, I'm busy -- That's  right, I said hammerhead, as in a  ten-letter word for a smug bullying  self-important newspaperman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Morris:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Gnu --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who couldn't find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Morris:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- That's G-N-U --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- couldn't find the Empire State  Building with a compass, a road map  and a native guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Morris:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- or emu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams down the phone. To Smitty:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And that's just the potatoes,  Smitty, here comes the gravy: The  chump really likes me. A Muncie girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smitty bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better off falling for a rattlesnake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she continues to type:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' ya, this guy's just the  patsy and I'm gonna find out what  for. There's a real story, Smitty,  some kind of plot, a setup, a cabal,  a -- oh, and say, did I tell ya?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't offer you money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sawbuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten dollars? Let's grab a highball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Norville Barnes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rips the page out of the typewriter, swivels in her c to FACE CAMERA as we TRACK IN CLOSE and she hollers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Copy!

dialogues.speaker: PRESSES
dialogues.text: rolling, churning out great quantities of newsprint. Papers piling up one on top of the other, very many, very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY MAN
dialogues.text: throwing a baled stack of papers off the back of his truc

dialogues.speaker: BALED PAPER
dialogues.text: rolling into the f.g. A hand ENTERS FRAME to snip its wir and wipe off the top paper.

dialogues.speaker: PAPER BOY
dialogues.text: wearing an apron and a little paper boy cap, mouthing "Ex Extra!" as he holds one of the papers aloft. PAN UP his arm TO the newspaper and, BEYOND it, the tower Hudsucker Building. All of the above --

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: spinning TOWARDS the CAMERA and STOPPING FULL FRAME. Its headline, over a picture of Norville smiling, is "IMB HEADS HUDSUCKER." The subheadline: "Not a Brain in his He

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: is angrily slammed down to reveal that Norville has been  reading the inside. His face twisting with fury, he leans forward and hits th intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Smith, can you come in please  to take a letter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muttering to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of all the cockamamie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy is bustling in holding a steno pad and a pencil. As she seats herself in front of his desk, he rises to pa behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Did you happen to see the front  page of today's Manhattan Argus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I... didn't bother to read the  article. I didn't think the picture  did you justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picture was fine! It's what that  knuckle-headed dame wrote underneath!  Of all the irresponsible... Amy,  take this down: Dear Miss Archer. I  call you 'Miss' because you seem to  have 'missed' the boat completely on  this one! How on earth would you  know whether I'm an imbecile when  you don't even have the guts to come  in here and interview me man to man!  No, change 'guts' to 'courage.' No,  make it 'common decency.' These wild  speculations about my intelligence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- or lack thereof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) -- these preposterous inventions,  would be better suited to the pages  of Amazing Tales Magazine. If the  editors of the Manhattan Argus see  fit to publish the rantings of a  disordered mind, perhaps they will  see fit to publish this letter! But  I doubt it. I most seriously doubt  it. As I doubt also that you could  find a home at Amazing Tales, a  periodical which I have enjoyed for  many years. Yours sincerely, et  cetera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drifts into thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all, Mr. Barnes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, you know me, Amy, at least  better than that that dame does. Do  you think I'm an imbecile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, tell the truth; I trust you  and I put a lot of stock in your  opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure, you're biased -- you're a  fellow Muncian. But would an imbecile  come up with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whips the cover sheet off a display pad resting on an  easel to reveal a large piece of graph paper with a circl rendered onto it. Amy looks, puzzled, from the circle to Norville's proudly beaming face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I designed it myself and this is  just the sweet baby that can put  Hudsucker right back on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy is bewildered. Norville explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know! For kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why don't I just type this up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aww, naw, Amy, that won't be  necessary. I shouldn't send it; she's  just doing her job, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know; maybe she does  deserve it. Maybe she should've come  in to face you man to man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she probably had a deadline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but -- she could still have  gotten your side for the record!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's done now -- what's the  use of grousing about it. Forget the  letter, Amy, I just had to blow off  some steam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up to leave, and is heading for the door when  Norville adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She's probably just a little  confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy turns at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know, probably one of these  fast-talking career gals, thinks  she's one of the boys. Probably is  one of the boys, if you know what I  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through clenched  teeth) I'm quite sure I don't know what you  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know. Suffers from one of  these complexes they have nowadays.  Seems pretty obvious, doesn't it?  She's probably very unattractive and  bitter about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know. Probably dresses in  men's clothing, swaps drinks with  the guys at the local watering hole,  and hobnobs with some smooth talking  heel in the newsroom named Biff or  Smoocher or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. And I bet she's ugly. Real ugly. Otherwise, why wouldn't  they print her picture next to her  byline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she puts her work ahead of her  personal appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet that's exactly what she tells  herself! But you and I both know  she's just a dried-up bitter old  maid. Say, how about you and I grab  a little dinner and a show after  work? I was thinking maybe The King  and I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whap! Amy slaps him. He stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How about Oklahoma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she stalks out of the office:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville Barnes, you don't know a  thing about that woman! You don't  know who she really is! And only a  numbskull thinks he knows things  about things he knows nothing about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares, rubbing his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what gives?

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: Reading five o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: WORKERS
dialogues.text: Rising from their desks, collecting personal effects, put on their hats and coats.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CLOCK
dialogues.text: Busy hands punch out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the executive floor. A security man walks down the hal whistling, swinging a ring of keys. After he passes the d to the ladies' room it opens, Amy peeks out, emerges, goe into Norville's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
