dialogues.text: She goes to the desk, takes out the appointment book, fli through it.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Still empty except for the one date with the Wilkie Gramm School Junior Achievers Club, which now has a red line dr across it with the notation CANCELED.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: looks around the office -- notices something.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Set into the wall to one side it is topped by a small pla AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY. Amy tries the knob, which turns, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is big and dim, several stories high, with spiral  staircases reaching into, and catwalks criss-crossing, th gloom above. It is filled with contraptions -- works, cog gears. There is no window, but on what would be the windo wall there is an enormous iron ring with a metal rod swee an interior circle. It is the backside of the great Hudsu clock. Amy gazes about. She crosses to a door opposite the one s entered from. She stoops to peek through its keyhole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are LOOKING INTO Sidney J. Mussburger's office. Mussburger sits at his desk barking into a Dictaphone. CLICK-CLICK-CLICK -- the PERPETUAL MOTION BALLS on his de are going full-tilt; THRUMMMMMMM -- the CLOCK'S exterior  second hand sweeps a shadow across the office. Mussburger, it seems, never sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memo. From the desk of Sidney J. Mussburger. Executive order number  530 slash A49. To: Director of the  Jacksonville Facility. Copies to:  Legal Affairs, Business Affairs,  Central Files. Re: Movement of Raw  Materials from the Huron Facility.  Due to unfavorable news in the slag  markets, Jacksonville inventory must  be reduced by 15 percent with overflow  diverted to the Waukegan Stamping  Facility. Memo. From the desk of  Sidney J. Mussburger. Executive order  number 530 slash A50. To: Director  of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watchoo doin' down they, Miss Archuh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She straightens and turns. Facing her is a very old BLACK MAN in a janitor's jumpsui with HUDSUCKER INDUSTRIES/The Future Is Now emblazoned ac it. We might recognize his voice as that of the narrator opened the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? How did you know who I  am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah guess ole Moses knows jes about  ever'thing, leastways if it concerns  Hudsuckuh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- who are you -- what d'you do  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah keeps the ol' circle turning --  this ol' clock needs plenty o' care.  Time is money, Miss Archuh, and money --  it drives that ol' global economy  and keeps big Daddy Earth a-spinnin'  on 'roun'. Ya see, without that  capital fo'mation --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Say, you won't tell anyone  about me, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't tell no one nothin' lessen  they ask. Thatches ain't ole Moses'  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you know everything about  Hudsucker, tell me why the Board  decided to make Norville Barnes  president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that even surprised ole Moses  at fust. I didn't think the Board  was that smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That smart?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then I figured it out: they did  it 'cause they figured young Norville  for an imbecile. Like some othuh  people ah know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why on earth would they want a nitwit  to be president?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause they's little pigglies! They's tryin' to inspire panic, make  that stock git cheap so's they can  snitch it all up fo' themselves! But  Norville, he's got some tricks up  his sleeve, he does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws a circle with his finger in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you know, fo' kids? Yeah, he's a  smart one, that Norville, heh-heh,  he's a caution. Wal, some folks is  square, an' some is hip --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To punctuate, he gives a little jerk of his hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But I guess you don't really know  him any better than that board does,  do ya, Miss Archuh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' only some kind a knucklehead  thinks she knows things 'bout things  she, uh -- when she don't, uh --  How'd that go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bristling) It's hardly the same --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you don't even know y'own self --  you ain't exactly the genuine article  are you, Miss Archuh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in connection with my job,  sometimes I have to go undercover as  it were --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean that! Why you pretendin'  to be such a hard ol' sourpuss! Ain't  never gonna make you happy! Never  made Warin' happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) I'm happy enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Okay, Miss Archuh. (turns and walks away) ...I got gears to see to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls after him) I'm plenty happy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is answered only by WHIRRING MACHINERY.

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: Elsewhere in the great room, he is hunkered down next to catchment which he buffs with a greasy rag. Amy's VOICE E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself) Them po' young folks. Looks like  Norville's in fo' the same kind o'  heartache ol' Warin' had. But then,  she never axed me 'bout dat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As OMINOUS MUSIC SWELLS, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams down a typescript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't print this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not, it's all true! The board is  using this poor guy! They're  depressing the stock so they can buy  it cheap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pure speculation! Why, they'd  have my butt in a satchel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Ol' satchel-butt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know they're gonna buy that stock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know anything! Fact is  they haven't bought it! The stock is  cheap, Archer! What're they waiting  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy's hunches are usually pretty  good, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't accuse someone of stock  manipulation on a hunch, Ignatz! The readers of the Manhattan Argus  aren't interested in sensationalism,  gossip and unsupported speculation.  Facts, figures -- those are the tools  of the newspaper trade! Why it's  almost as if you're trying to take  the heat off this Barnes numbskull --  like you've gone all soft on him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Chief, that's a low blow. Archer's not gonna go goey for a  corn-fed idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I was out of line. But  you're out of line with this stock  swindle story. Gimme some more of  that Moron-from-Sheboygan stuff --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muncie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever. That's what sells  newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an even hotter story -- The Sap from the City Desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it, Archer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about a dimwitted editor who --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, Amy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a companionable goose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Let's grab a highball and calm  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She whirls and slaps him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back off -- smoocher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smitty rubs his cheek, staring as she storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Say, what gives?

dialogues.speaker: IT READS
dialogues.text: Sidney J. Mussburger President Norville Barnes and The Bo of Hudsucker Industries CORDIALLY INVITE YOU TO The Annua Fancy-Dress Hudsucker Christmas Gala Music, Dancing,  Refreshments (Dainties) Formal Evening Attire de Rigeuer. The MUSIC OVER the invitation -- "WE WISH YOU A MERRY  CHRISTMAS" -- SEGUES INTO the dance music of the Hudsucke Chamber Orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING COUPLES
dialogues.text: FILL the SCREEN; we GLIDE AMONG them and FINALLY COME to  follow one couple: Norville and MRS. MUSSBURGER, a large  middle-aged woman of the Margaret Dumont-mold in an  elaborately flowered and old-fashioned evening gown, low- in spite of her overly-heavy figure. She wears a large  flowered hat with a rolled-up veil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- So we'd gone out to the Hamptons  and the garden was in positive ruins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have been quite a  disappointment, Mrs. Mussburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointment? J'etais destroyee! I  was in bed for a week! Positively  sick with fury! I called in the  gardener and said, 'Monsieur Gonzalez,  either those azaleas come up next  spring or you are terminee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her head back and roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR FEET
dialogues.text: As the large woman leans back to laugh, her feet stay pla on the ground and Norville's rise to be dragged with his  toes scraping the floor through the continuing dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm brushing up on my French with  the most charming man, Pierre of  Fifth Avenue. Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't had --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney and I are planning a trip to  Paris and points continental -- Aren't we, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger has ENTERED FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. I'm going to borrow  Norville for a while, if you don't  mind, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIXING DOWN as they leave her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, frankly, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a charming wife, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they tell me. Norville, let me  shepherd you through some of the  introductions here. Try not to talk  too much; some of our biggest  stockholders are, uh -- scratch that:  Say whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRYWAY
dialogues.text: As Amy enters in a simple yet stunning evening gown. She  looks around the room, then starts across the crowded flo towards the punch bowl.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: As Mussburger introduces him to a tall, imposing BUSINESS in a tuxedo and a ten-gallon hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville Barnes, allow me to introduce  Mr. Zebulon Cardozo, one of Hudsucker  Industries largest and most loyal  stockholders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring Norville's proffered hand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit boy, what's this I hear about  you bein' an embecile? What the hell  is ailin' ya?! A week ago my stock  was worth twice what it is now! I'm  considering dumping the whole shootin'  match, unless I see some vast  improvement! Dammit, boy, It's a  range war! Either you pull our wagons  into a circle or I'm pullin' out of  the wagon train!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville gives him a forced but hearty laugh of reassuran

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need for concern, sir; it's only  natural in a period of transition  for the more timid element to run  for cover --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm yella, am I?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts peeling off his tuxedo jacket:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We'll see who's yella!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His WIFE, a small wiry woman, steps in as Mussburger star dragging Norville away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zebulon, you mind now and quit bein'  sech an ole grizzly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reluctantly starts shrugging back into the jacket:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aww, I wasn't gonna hurt the boy,  Lorelei...

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER AND NORVILLE
dialogues.text: As they make their way through the room Norville is moppi at his brow with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sid, I thought maybe if I  showed him the long view we might --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thump! Dabbing at his brow, Norville has walked square in the back of a debonaire man holding a martini. The drink sloshes and the man turns testily to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, this is Thorstensen  Finlandsen, who heads a radical  splinter group of disgruntled  investors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville nervously pumps Findlandsen's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Finlandsen, so sorry to  meet you -- uh, happy to walk into y --  uh, pleased to make your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findlandsen raises his hand to look quizzically at Norvil handkerchief which he now holds himself, apparently havin been given it during the handshake. He hands it back to Norville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stuffs it nervously into his outside breast pocket as  Findlandsen stares at him. Mussburger stands watching in executive at-ease, hands dug into his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I understand your concern about  the down-ward, you know, but I think  you'll find under our strong new  leadership...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norville's hand drops from his breast pocket the  handkerchief, perhaps caught on his sleeve, whips out of pocket and follows his hand down. Findlandsen looks down and Norville follows his look, and stoops BELOW FRAME to retrieve the hanky. Findlandsen leans quizzically forward and peers down at  Norville, who continues, O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We anticipate, in short order, an  upward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In rapid fire, Norville straightens up into -- crunch --  Findlandsen, whose head snaps back, eyes rolling, a hand  pressed to his nose, drink sloshing; Norville, one hand  pressed to the back of his own head and the other wildly  waving his hanky for balance, takes a staggering step for onto the toe of an elegantly-gowned MRS. FINDLANDSEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a drum roll and, as the lights dim:

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: grabs the large old-fashioned microphone in front of the  band and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, distinguished  members of the Hudsucker board. I  give you the king of swing, the rajah  of romance, the incredible, the  unforgettable Mister Vic... Tenetta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic Tenetta takes the microphone from the Emcee who backs away, applauding as Tenetta starts to croon. He wears a w dinner jacket. His jet black hair sweeps out over his for in a roguishly pompadoured mat; one forelock droops and  bounces across his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL BOARD MEMBERS
dialogues.text: Clustered in a dim corner of the room, smoking cigars. In the b.g., brilliantly spotlit, Vic Tenetta continues h song. As Mussburger joins them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going, Mr. Mussburger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not bad enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be better, it could be worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stock's got to drop another five  points if we expect to get controlling  interest. Norville tells me he's got  some hot idea. Can't be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it can't be bad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't be better if it couldn't be  worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where the PARTY NOISE is DISTANT, TENETTA'S SONG just  FILTERING OUT. We are on a FULL SHOT of the back of a man who stands fac the twinkling cityscape, but in an odd, leanedback postur with one hand reaching up to his hidden face, his other h pressed against the small of his back, like a man with a  stiff neck tossing back a drink.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Amy, having just emerged onto the terrace, squints at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Norville?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and we see that it is indeed Norville, holding a dripping icepack against one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Nothing, really, just... the  more timid investors are no longer  running for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid found me the icepack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me hold it, or you'll have a  real shiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. People seem to be pretty hot  over this imbecile story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it isn't your fault, Amy. You're the one person who's been  standing by me through all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she rolls the pack gently across his eye:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville... there's something I have  to tell you. You see, I'm not really  a secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that you're not very  skilled yet in the secretarial arts.  I'm not that skilled as president.  Oh sure, I put up a big front -- (massages his eye) -- not that everyone's buying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in you, Norville -- At least I believe in your...  intentions --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't blame them, really. I  guess I have sort of made a mess of  things. These folks have to protect  their investment. Most of them are  very nice people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, you can't trust people  here like you did in Muncie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gaze out at the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Certain people are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didja ever go to the top of old man  Larson's feed tower and look out  over the town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, on farm route 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes! In Muncie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! In Vidalia! Farm Route 17!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- Yes. Seventeen. Yes, I -- well  no, I -- I never really... There's a  place I go now, the cutest little  place near my apartment in Greenwich  Village. It's called Ann's 440. It's  a beatnik bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you can get carrot juice or  Italian coffee, and the people there --  well, none of them quite fit in.  You'd love it -- why don't you come  there with me -- they're having a  marathon poetry reading on New Year's  Eve. I go every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Every year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- this year -- if it's good I  plan to make it a tradition. Uh, my  it certainly is beautiful --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods out at the city to avoid Norville's quizzical lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The people look like ants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the Hindus say -- and the  beatniks also -- that in the next  life some of us will come back as  ants. Some will be butterflies. Others will be elephants or creatures  of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you were in your  previous life, Amy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Maybe I was just a  fast-talking career gal who thought  she was one of the boys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Amy, pardon me for saying so  but I find that very farfetched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, there really is something  I have to tell you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of person would come back  as a wildebeest, or a warthog. No, I  think it more likely that you were a  gazelle, with long, graceful legs,  gamboling through the underbrush.  Perhaps we met once, a chance  encounter in a forest glade. I must  have been an antelope or an ibex.  What times we must have had --  foraging together for sustenance,  picking the grubs and burrs from one  another's coats. Or perhaps we simply  touched our horns briefly and went  our separate ways...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it were that simple, Norville.  I wish I was still a gazelle, and  you were an antelope or an ibex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, can I at least call you deer?  Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha! Seriously, Amy, the  whole thing is what your beatnik  friends call 'karma' -- the great  circle of life, death and rebirth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morosely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think I've heard of that. What goes around comes around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. A great wheel that gives  us each what we deserve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps his fist into his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tomorrow's my big presentation to  the board. I've gotta show Sidney  and the guys that I deserve all their  confidence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Norville --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss me once, Amy! Kiss me once for  luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Norville, sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a peck. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh, Norville!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She embraces him. They kiss again. Norville's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: VIC TENETTA
dialogues.text: Crooning the end of his song.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING COUPLES
dialogues.text: Turn to the bandstand and applaud.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE AND AMY
dialogues.text: In the midst of a passionate kiss.

dialogues.speaker: DOUBLE OAK DOORS
dialogues.text: Labeled "Executive Conference Room." A secretary is hangi up a sign that reads: "Quiet Please! Board Meeting in  Session."

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Chest and up. His upper torso is swaying, his shoulders  rhythmically rolling as he talks. We hear a WHOOSH WHOOSH sound from O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- So we have economy, simplicity,  low production cost and the potential  for mass appeal, and all that spells  out great profitability...

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER
dialogues.text: Staring. Holding a just-lighted but forgotten cigar in on hand, and a still burning match in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I had the boys down at R & D throw  together this prototype so that our  discussion here could have some  focus...

dialogues.speaker: BOARD
dialogues.text: Staring, mouths hanging open, in arrested motion much lik when Waring Hudsucker jumped out the window at the previo board meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and to give you gentlemen of the  Board a first-hand look at just how  exciting this gizmo is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still gyrating. We now see that he has accelerated the hu hoop around his waist to quite a good speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's fun, it's healthy, it's good  exercise; kids'll just love it, and  we put a little sand inside to make  the whole experience more pleasant.  And the great part is we won't have  to charge an arm and a leg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mussburger's forgotten match has burned down to his  fingertips. With a wince, he shakes it out. The Board is staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but... What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have rules?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can more than one play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to #3) What makes you think it's a game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better break eventually!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there an object?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to make it fly off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it come with batteries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we charge extra for them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it safe for toddlers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell when you're done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you make it stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a girl's model or a boy's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can a parent assemble it??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you get tired before it's  done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a larger model for the obese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do it around your neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally... what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, for kids! It's... it's ...  well, it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Board looks at Mussburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's genius. It's just exactly  what Hudsucker needs at this juncture.  Sure, sure, a blind man could tell  you that there's an enormous demand  for this, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles weakly at Norville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Congratulations, kid, you've really  outdone yourself. Reinvented the  wheel. I'm going to recommend to the  Board that we proceed immediately  with this, uh... with the, uh...  that the dingus be mass-produced  with all deliberate speed. Of course,  as president of the company the  ultimate decision is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm for it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As furiously BUSY MUSIC STARTS:

dialogues.speaker: TELETYPE
dialogues.text: Furiously PRINTING out "EXECUTIVE DIRECTIVE #37451-JL7. A hand ENTERS FRAME and rips the directive from the telet then hurriedly rolls it into a cylinder and slips it into cylindrical metal capsule. The capsule is popped into a pneumatic tube.

dialogues.speaker: LENGTH OF PNEUMATIC PIPING
dialogues.text: somewhere in the labyrinthine substructure of the Hudsuck Building. We hear a MISSILE furiously HURTLING towards us inside the pipe, and ROCKETING by.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER LENGTH OF PIPING
dialogues.text: Once again we hear the CAPSULE APPROACH and ROCKET past.

dialogues.speaker: BLINDING RED LIGHTS
dialogues.text: as a SIREN BLARES. On a huge board that says HUDSUCKER DE DEPARTMENT, flashing red letters announce: INCOMING DIREC The pneumatic tube spout shoots out a cylinder, and a han eagerly picks it up and yanks it OUT OF FRAME. A technician in white laboratory smock is reading the  directive as several other white-jacketed technicians cro their heads around his shoulders, also reading. All of their eye and head motions synchronize as they eag read, devouring the document line by line. A large sheet of graph paper is whipped down on top of a  drafting table. Under the caption OVERHEAD ANGLE is a per circle. Under the caption HORIZONTAL is a horizontal line Under the caption VERTICAL SIDE ANGLE is a vertical line.

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL TECHNICIANS
dialogues.text: looking thoughtfully down at the rendering. The head  technician is stroking his beard and nodding.

dialogues.speaker: RENDERING
dialogues.text: as a hand ENTERS FRAME and stamps the drawing approved.

dialogues.speaker: TWO MORE LENGTHS OF PNEUMATIC PIPE
dialogues.text: as we hear the CYLINDER ROCKETING by.

dialogues.speaker: FROSTED DOUBLE GLASS DOORS
dialogues.text: Lettered on the frosted glass is: "ADVERTISING DEPARTMENT Creative Bullpen." In sharp silhouette on the frosted gla we can see the three admen working inside. Two pace back and forth, smoking cigarettes, as they toss out ideas. The third sits slumped in front of a silhouett typewriter, his head resting on one hand, his other hand  resting on a half-empty bottle of whiskey. In the f.g., outside the frosted glass and so not in  silhouette, sits a bored secretary reading War and Peace, Volume One.

dialogues.text: We'll call it the Flying Donut!

dialogues.text: The Dancing Dingus!

dialogues.text: With the cylinder rocketing by.

dialogues.text: Up on the wall of the accounting floor is an enormous  reproduction of the design department's rendering of the  hula hoop. Over the poster is an enormous banner: "WHAT W

dialogues.text: Being dropped onto a desk. Its cover reads: SUMMARY OF CO ANALYSIS. The book is opened and its pages, filled with rows of num are flipped to the last page where we QUICKLY PAN DOWN TO the bottom line: Unit Cost... $0.59 Suggested Retail... $

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Looking down at the book as the head accountant hovers ov his shoulder, waiting for his reaction. The executive grimly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: As the accountant's hand ENTERS FRAME to scratch in "$1" front of the suggested retail of $0.79. A hand ENTERS FRAME to stamp the bottom line: APPROVED.

dialogues.speaker: ADVERTISING DEPARTMENT CREATIVE BULLPEN
dialogues.text: The secretary in the f.g. is now reading War and Peace, V Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snappy.

dialogues.text: With a little jazz.

dialogues.text: The Shazzammeter!

dialogues.text: The Hipster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drawing a circle in the air:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Daddy-Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Circle-o'-Gaiety!

dialogues.text: in asbestos suits throwing down their visors as they scur and dive for cover behind banks of sandbags. A fierce  EXPLOSION harshly illuminates the sandbags. As the EXPLOS

dialogues.speaker: SUBSIDES
dialogues.text: The workmen cautiously peek out over the sandbags, then f back their visors and rise to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouncing among the flaming debris of the explosion is a h hoop, still intact.

dialogues.text: The secretary in the f.g. is now reading Anna Karenina. The silhouetted ad men, frustrated and hoarse, are still it.

dialogues.text: Ya got somethin'?

dialogues.text: Ya got somethin'?!

dialogues.text: Fellas! I got somethin'!

dialogues.text: Printed at the top: Hudsucker Industries Proudly Presents PAN DOWN to reveal: THE HULA HOOP PAN DOWN to reveal: An artist's hand working in fast motion to render the hul hoop logo: A grinning, healthy 1950s boy with a spray of  freckles, one fist thrown forward, the other behind, as i doing an athletic frug, a hula hoop spinning with action  lines around his waist. In seconds the artist has completed the logo and now, als in fast motion, he writes the slogan on either side of th boy: "You know... For Kids!" As the page is ripped off the art pad:

dialogues.speaker: PAGE
dialogues.text: being carried away in a continuous motion by an engineer looks at it, nodding. We see that we are now in an enormo plant area. The engineer, grimy from his labors in this s industrial realm, reaches up to pull an enormous lever.

dialogues.speaker: MACHINES
dialogues.text: GRINDING into motion.

dialogues.speaker: DONUT SPOUT
dialogues.text: As it begins to spit hula hoops in massive numbers. The hoops are spit onto a long metal arm where they rest, hanging. A bale of hula hoops is loaded into a Hudsucker truck to  complete its load. The truck door is slammed shut.

dialogues.text: is thrown up to reveal the display window of a shop just  opening for the day. Reflected in the display window we see crowds of people  scurrying by, indifferent to the display. Inside the shop see the proprietor by the cash register, his chin propped glumly in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville sits anxiously awaiting the verdict of Amy who s hunched over the ticker-tape machine, studying the emergi tape. Amy finally looks up at Norville and sadly shakes h head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SHOP WINDOW
dialogues.text: Crowds still scurry indifferently by. The shopkeeper stan idly in his doorway, smoking a cigarette. We TRACK IN ON the cardboard display. The displayed price $1.79 has been crossed out. Underneath it, inked in: "Red

dialogues.text: The old $1.59 is suddenly covered as the hand ENTERS FRAM to slap on a sticker: $1.49. A beat. The hand ENTERS FRAM to slap on a new sticker: $1.29. Then in rapid-fire  succession: $0.99. $0.79. $0.49. Two for $0.25. Free with any purchase.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY BEHIND SHOP
dialogues.text: where garbage and garbage cans sit waiting for collection Hands appear at the back door of a shop hurling a clutch hoops towards the trash heap. One errant hoop rolls towar the mouth of the alley. The mouth of the alley. The escaped hula hoop emerges and starts rolling down the street.

dialogues.speaker: HULA HOOP
dialogues.text: It rolls across the street. CARS VIOLENTLY BRAKE to avoid it. It rounds a corner and rolls up to a little boy, rolls in circle around him, and finally wobbles to the pavement. The little boy looks at it, steps inside it, raises it to his hips and starts hula hooping. Somewhere a BELL is RIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where the BELL is RINGING, the front doors fly open and  hundreds of schoolchildren run out, screaming, heading ho but all in a dense pack. The screaming pack of schoolchildren round a corner and - stop short, their screams abruptly halting. They are staring, fascinated, at the hula-hooping youngst The children are dumbfounded. It is a moment the likes of which they have never dreamed.

dialogues.speaker: SCREAMING PACK
dialogues.text: once again running, maniacal, possessed. We don't know wh they are running, but we can guess.

dialogues.speaker: STORE
dialogues.text: Jam-packed with screaming children, grabbing hula hoops o the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO NORVILLE'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Norville sits slumped behind his desk, his head resting o the desktop, utterly dejected. Suddenly the TICKER-TAPE HUMS to life and starts spitting tape. Amy looks at it with mounting excitement. Finally s looks breathlessly up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Norville!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville lifts his head from the desktop. A piece of scra paper is sticking to his cheek. Dramatic FANFARE MUSIC ST TO SWELL. We HOLD ON Norville's expectant face. We HOLD. The MUSIC  BUILDS. We HOLD. We:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL TITLE
dialogues.text: We can see the "Tidbits of Time" logo as a solemn-voiced  announcer intones:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rockwell News presents... 'Tidbits  of Time!' World news in pictures, we  kid you not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picture dissolves to a pan up the Hudsucker Building. Cut to candid film of Norville getting out of a car, noti the camera, grinning and waving as he walks, and taking a pratfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What began as the brainchild of  this Madison Avenue whiz kid is now  a craze sweeping the nation. The  'hula hoop,' product of Hudsucker  Industries, is a recreational device  that some experts predict may eclipse  the television as a means of  entertainment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A television sits against a neutral b.g. A hula hoop roll into frame and bumps the TV, pushing it out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This dancing dingus of delight,  this jerky circle of gaiety, is  proving to be the toy of choice of  most American youngsters. -- Whoa- ho! Did I say youngsters?! Here's  mom, taking a break from her household  chores...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman switches off her vacuum cleaner, takes a hula hoo that is conveniently leaning against a nearby wall, and s hula hooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and even dad is 'swinging' into  the act!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the office, dad, smoking a pipe, is also hula hooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and so the congratulations pour  in for up-and-comer Norville Barnes,  inventor of the hoop -- including  one very special call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In jerky cinema-verite footage, a woman is excitedly stic her head in Norville's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on! He's on the line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swish over to Norville, agog, who picks up his phone and, voice breaking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Norville. This is the  President...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-wipe leaves a split screen with half of the screen remaining Norville, the other half becoming a still of Ik standing in a tank turret, pointing commandingly. Under the photo: VOICE OF GENERAL DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just wanted to congratulate  you. I'm very proud of you,  Norville...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mrs. Eisenhower is very proud of  you. The American people are very  proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flash bulb explosion effects a...

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Facing a battery of REPORTERS at a news conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, how'd ya come up with  the idea for the hula hoop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville is holding one hand up to shield his eyes from t unaccustomed light. Amy stands next to him, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was no great idea, really.  A thing like this, it takes a whole  company to put it together, and I'm  just grateful for the opportunity --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, did you have any idea  there'd be such a huge response?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, frankly, I don't think anybody  expected this much hoopla --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is surprised by a burst of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Hoopla on the hula hoop' -- can we  quote you on that, Mr. Barnes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sure, I guess --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, are you thinking of giving  yourself a nice fat raise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha-ha-ha-ha. Come on, guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flash bulb explosion effects a...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL
dialogues.text: A scientist with a Van Dyke beard, wearing a laboratory s is facing the camera. Behind him we see other scientists  studying a hoop that has been hooked up to a gyroscopic- looking device that analyzes its various movements and  properties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scientific principle explains  the mind-bending motion of this  whipping wheel of wonder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title supered over the Scientist's chest identifies him Professor Erwin Schweide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ze dinkus is kvite zimple, really. It operates on ze same principle zat  keeps ze earth spinning 'round ze  sun, and zat keeps you from flying  off ze earth into ze coldest reaches  of outer space vere you vood die  like a miserable shvine! Yes, ze  principle is ze same, except for ze  piece of grrrit zey put in to make  ze whole experience more pleasant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mean laugh. Norville, behind his desk in LONG SHOT,  laughing, as we begin to TRACK IN. There is something  disconcerting about his laugh -- it is harder, more  businesslike, colder than the dopey laugh that accompanie his elevation to the presidency. Or perhaps it is only ou imagination, for while still some distance away from him: Flash bulb explosion effects a...

dialogues.speaker: NEWS CONFERENCE
dialogues.text: Newsmen follow Norville as he walks through the lobby of Hudsucker Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, did the board consider  you an 'idea man' when they promoted  you from the mail room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess so -- I don't think  they promoted me because they thought  I was a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, what's the next big idea  for you and Hudsucker Industries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, I don't know. An idea like  this sweet baby doesn't just come  overnight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, are you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Although I'll tell you one thing:  I certainly didn't expect all this  'hoopla'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This TIRED old joke brings some polite laughter. Norville is smiling as he enters the elevator. As its doo start to close, leaving Amy behind:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And you can quote me on that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flash bulb explosion effects a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's hula hula everywhere! From  the cocktail parties of the Park  Avenue smart set...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of people in formal evening wear are sipping high and chatting as they keep hoops in motion 'round their wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to sweethearts who want to be  married in the 'swing' of things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young couple stands before the altar hula hooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...To our friend the Negro, in the  heart of the dark continent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pan down from elephant to two natives hula hooping as the grin into the newsreel camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mean laugh. Yes, as we draw closer, it seems clear th his laugh is colder than before. Flash bulb explosion effects a...

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Sitting in a barber chair, face lathered up, as Reporters crowd in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, Mr. Barnes, Rumpus  magazine has called you the most  eligible bachelor of the year, and  the society pages have been linking  you with high-fashion model Za-Za.  Would you care to comment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burning cigar emerges from the lather around Norville's face. It waggles as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no truth to the rumors; we're  just dear friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Isn't that right, Za-Za?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZA-ZA. Standing nearby. Every man's dream, in a tarty sor of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sexily) Gr-r-r-r-r-r-r-oww!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newsmen react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho-leeee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnes, whither Hudsucker? Whither Norville Barnes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you respond to the charges  that you're out of ideas? Has Norville  Barnes run dry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barber is periodically pinching Norville's nose to sh under it; as he alternately pinches and releases, Norvill voice breaks from nasal to normal and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Why, just this week I  came up with several new sweet ideas.  A larger model hula hoop for the  portly. A battery option for the  lazy and handicapped. A model with  more sand for hard-of-hearing. I'm  earning my keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of that, Mr. Barnes, do you  expect to get a raise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, by anyone's account I've saved  Hudsucker Industries; our stock is  worth more than it's ever been. So,  yes, I expect to be compensated for  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mean laugh. FURTHER TRACK IN ON Norville ENDS in CLOS SHOT, his hands clasped on the desktop in front of him, a he finishes his hard, square-jawed, man-on-top laugh, gaz flintily INTO the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- ha-ha-ha-ha-ha!

dialogues.speaker: WEEPING EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: The PULL BACK FROM a blubbering executive REVEALS that we are at a Board meeting. All of the Board members sit arou the table except for Mussburger, who, a towel around his  waist, is receiving a choppity-chop massage on a padded t from a muscular man in a bulging T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together, Addison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Addison snuffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody told me! Nobody told me! You sold all of our stock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dumped the whole load. Now quit  showboating, Addison --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had twenty thousand shares! I'd be  a millionaire now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, we'd all be millionaires.  There's no point in looking back. At  the time, Stilson thought dumping  our position would panic the market,  further depress the stock -- then  we'd buy it all back, and more of  course, once it got cheap --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheap! Cheap! It's never been more  valuable! And I'm ruined! Ruined!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs up onto the board table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting off this merry-go-round!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Addison!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaahhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs down the length of the table and hurls himself to the window and: Thwok!

dialogues.speaker: MUSSBURGER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: LOOKING IN, as Addison flattens against the f.g. glass, h face squushing, his outflung hands likewise. All stare in horror for a long silent beat. With the sound of a SQUEEGEE being drawn across glass,  Addison, still frozen, slides down the window, hits the f and falls stiffly back like a fallen tree. Mussburger sits up and sticks a cigar into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plexiglas. Had it installed last  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Myron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, so the kid caught a wave.  So right now he and his dingus are  on top. Well, this too shall pass.  Myrtle J. Mussburger didn't raise  her boy to go knockkneed at the first  sign of adversity. I say, we made  this kid and we can break him. I  say, the higher he climbs, the harder  he drops. I say, yes, the kid has a  future, and in it I see shame,  dishonor, ignominy and disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, the wheel turns, the music plays, and our spi ain't over yet.

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: A small chamber orchestra, the musicians in tails, sit pl "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik". Norville, eyes closed, reclines his desk chair, one uniformed woman stooping in front of  him, manicuring his nails, another, behind, massaging his temples. A tailor is pinning up his pant cuffs. A French sculptor wearing a white smock, a beret, and a g squints at Norville and chisels at a block of marble with stone chisel and hammer. A GOON sits off to one side, hat insolently atop his head reading the funny papers. At length Norville stirs, opens his eyes, sits bolt uprig batting away the hands of the manicurist and temple-massa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The musicians' playing dribbles away to silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nobody move, nobody breathe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All sit frozen. You could hear a pin drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...An idea... is coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes narrowed, he gazes off into space, squinting for his idea.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR'S KIT
dialogues.text: A straight pin is rolling across the top -- it drops off

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR
dialogues.text: Where the PIN -- PING! -- hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deflates. He glares at the tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The musicians resume playing. Everyone else resumes work. The INTERCOM BUZZES and a female voice announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Amy here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville leans forward to hit his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she in the book? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open and Amy storms in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Pete's sake, Norville!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Hello, Amy -- was it -- I thought  she said, Mamie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind about that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes a piece of paper at Norville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know what those nincompoops  in the boardroom are doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't call them nincom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to discharge eight  percent of the work force here at  Hudsucker. Why, in New York alone  that means eighteen hundred people  out of work, people with wives and  children and families --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yes, we're pruning away some of  the dead wood, but if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know about it? You think the Board  would do anything like this without  my authorization? No, this was my  idea from the start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your i --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to be realistic, Amy. You  know things have slowed down a little  here at Hudsucker --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're awful kind to yourself,  Norville Barnes -- the fact is you've  slowed down, sitting up here like a  sultan, not doing a lick of work!  Why you know it's ideas that are the  lifeblood of industry and you haven't  come up with one since the hoop and  the reason's plain to see! You've  forgotten what made your ideas  exciting for you in the first place --  it wasn't for the fame and the wealth  and the mindless adulation of --  would you get out of here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was addressed to the chamber orchestra, whose playin dribbles off. They look inquisitively at Norville, then r to pack up their instruments and sheepishly leave the off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've been watching you, Norville  Barnes, even though you've been trying  to avoid me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Aim --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shutup! -- and don't think I haven't  noticed how you've changed. I used  to think you were a swell guy --  well, to be honest I thought you  were an imbecile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Aim --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shutup! -- but then I figured out  you were a swell guy, a little slow  maybe, but a swell guy! Well, maybe  you're not so slow, but you're not  so swell either and it looks like  you're an imbecile after --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Aim --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shutup! -- after all! You haven't  talked to me for a week and now I'm  going to say my piece. I've got a  prediction for you, Norville Barnes:  I predict that since you've decided  to dedicate yourself to greed and  sloth and everything bad, you're  going to lose all the good things  that your good ideas brought you. You're going to throw them all away  chasing after money and ease and the  respect of a Board that wouldn't  give you the time of day if you...  if you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worked in a watch factory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Goon looks up from his funnies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh-huh-huh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Goon) Shutup! (to Norville) Exactly! Don't you remember how you  used to feel about the hoop? You  told me you were gonna bring a smile  to the hips of everyone in America,  regardless of race, creed or color.  Finally there'd be a thingamajig  that would bring everyone together --  even if it kept 'em apart, spacially --  you know, for kids? Your words,  Norville, not mine. I used to love  Norville Barnes -- yes, love him! --  when he was just a swell kid with  hot ideas who was in over his head,  but now your head is too big to be  in over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Amy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider this my resignation --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thwock -- She slaps him. The bodyguard is on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack -- Amy kicks him hard in the shin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Awooooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Effective immediately!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strides to the door, leaving Norville rubbing his che and the Goon hopping around on one leg.

dialogues.speaker: PICTURE OF AMY
dialogues.text: PULL BACK SHOWS it to be her identification in her Hudsuc personnel file. A hand brings INTO FRAME another picture of her -- this o a newspaper clipping. She stands on a podium accepting an award; standing behind her are middle-aged identical trip The caption says, "Amy Archer of the Manhattan Argus Rece Pulitzer Prize."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in Mussburger's office. Mussburger is seated at hi desk looking at the file picture and clipping; the sign  letterer/scraper is leaning over his shoulder, having jus put them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm... Thank you, Aloysius. This  may be useful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloysious nods wordlessly and turns to leave. As we TRACK IN ON the picture of Amy, we:

dialogues.speaker: PERFECT WHITE
dialogues.text: After a beat, a woman ENTERS against the unblemished whit background, dressed in a flowing white dance robe, traili a long, diaphanous veil. She performs a flowingly sensuou dance moderne; the MUSIC is a sensuous saxophone solo wit lasciviously bending blue notes. After the woman has been dancing for several beats Norvil enters, dancing after her, pursuing her. He is wearing a  coatless suit, his sleeves rolled up, his thin tie loosen The woman dances around him, letting her diaphanous veil  trail sinuously around his body. We hear an ECHOING voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy... Say, buddy...

dialogues.speaker: NORVILLE
dialogues.text: Sitting in his desk chair, sheened with sweat, eyes close licking his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy... Ya busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh-whuh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens his eyes and looks stuporously about. Buzz is grinning down at him in his little pillbox elevat cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like ya nodded off there, buddy!  Say, ya got a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh... Buzz... Is it important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to think so! It's this little  idea I been working on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns an easel to face the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ya see, I don't intend to be an  elevator boy forever! Take a look at  this sweet baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The easel displays an oversized sheet of graph paper. Onto it has been rendered a top view, which is a perfect  circle, and a side view, which is a vertical line. Norville gazes stupidly at the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ya get it, buddy? Incredibly  convenient, isn't it? Ya see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a tall glass of lemonade with a straw sitting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- this is how it works, it's these  little ridges on the side that give  it its whammy! See, ya don't have to  drink like this anymore --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds his head over the glass to drink from the vertic straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Now you can drink like this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends the straw to drink from it at the horizontal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I call it the Buzz-Sucker, get  it, buddy? -- After me! Buzz! Why,  people are just dyin' for a product  like this, and the great thing is we  won't have to charge an arm and a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville, who has been stewing, finally barks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the lemonade glass, looks at it, sneering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why, this is worthless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?! But, buddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norville yanks the straw out and crumples it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most idiotic thing I've  ever seen in my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, buddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody wants a hare-brained product  like this! Ya see, Buzz, it lacks  the creative spark, the unalloyed  genius that made, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses to belch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...say, the hula hoop such a success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, buddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you mean barging in here  and taking up my valuable time! I've  got a company to run here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, buddy, you were --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I can't have every deadbeat on  the Hudsucker payroll pestering me  with their idiotic brainwaves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, I'm sorry, buddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An example must be made!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz looks over his shoulder, turns back to Norville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wuddya mean, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fired! You're fired! Is that plain  enough for you, buster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz's jaw drops. His elastic chin strap snaps under the  pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awwww, buddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't call me buddy! Out of here!  Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz sinks to his knees, weeping. He clutches patheticall at Norville's pants legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, please, sir -- this job, it's  all I got!
